body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

author.bio: 12/08/2021 The administrators are no longer committed to free speech on this website, but they will continue to develop the software so that anyone who is interested in hosting a free speech website can do so. Rest in peace, Ruqqus. It was nice.

body:
>moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account

Good change. It was rather clear that @JosephGoebbels was the main account, not only given its activity but also the user's obvious preference for the... unique... name.

>Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban

Bad change. Long live Chairman @carpathianflorist. The _coup_ is a _fait accompli_.

> also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds

Good change. I intended to suggest making it so that, rather than immediately being able to siege a guild, you'd have to wait a day or two after the ban, precisely to prevent this kind of situation (a mistake being exploited) in the future (without conceding that the existing siege, which is a fait accompli, should be reverted, which it shouldn't)

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

body:
To be honest, I'm not sure how it could be carried out in practice.  
Regarding sieged guilds: If you exile a ton of users and kick posts immediately, its easy to see you aren't a friend of that community.
Regarding guilds operated in bad faith in the first place, I'm not sure how that could be approached.  I'm aware there are a lot of guilds that are +anti[insertGroupOfPeopleIThinkAreEvil] that are created by and maintained for no reason but to block out their reddit counterparts and I also think that's bad faith (even if I despise their reddit counterparts).  The issue there is that it would require a more nuanced review of its content to undo those.  I don't wish that level of review on admins, and I frankly don't trust volunteer internet janitors to be impartial.

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

I would say that if someone is an unironic Nazi, and makes a pro-Nazi guild, that's in good faith regardless of perceived bad intentions.  Webster's dictionary defines Good Faith as "honesty or lawfulness of purpose".  A nazi honestly believes they are right.  
For a less charged metaphor, suppose I made a guild about late night snacking and I later was banned for legitimate reasons.  If someone sieges that guild and makes it about intermittent fasting and never eating outside of a strict 8 hour window, that would be outside of the intent of the guild.  The members joined to talk about eating snack food late at night, not to be lectured about how its bad for their health by someone who was never interested in sharing their view.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

> I would say that if someone is an unironic Nazi, and makes a pro-Nazi guild, that's in good faith regardless of perceived bad intentions. Webster's dictionary defines Good Faith as "honesty or lawfulness of purpose". A nazi honestly believes they are right.

No objection. You're right so far.

However, an unironic anti-nazi besieging a formerly nazi guild is also in good faith, under the same argument: that's in good faith regardless of perceived bad intentions. Webster's dictionary defines "good faith" as "honesty or lawfulness of purpose". An anti-nazi honestly believes he is right to besiege a nazi guild and put an end to the nazi propaganda.

Such a subjective rule could never be enforced.

To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. body:
As a new user, who is looking for a platform that values free speech, it is rather discouraging to see this kind of organized commandeering and defacing of guilds, for expressing controversial ideas, with clear and expressed intent to shut those ideas down and drive them out. Especially since it was allegedly done with assistance and blessing from the administration. 

Could you please clarify a few things, to help users like me decide if this platform is really what it claims to be?

The individuals who perpetrated the siege made this claim:

> All of this was possible due to @captainmeta4 's good communication and coordination with us, hopefully we can continue to clean up ruqqus together!

Is this true? Did you coordinate with them and thereby enable the siege?

> we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban

Does that include guilds like +GenderCriticaL and +AntiWhite, which were taken over more than 3 weeks ago? Why was there no intervention then?

> Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status

Does that mean that sieges, in general, are permitted? So having alts is a bannable offense, but maliciously stealing, defacing and destroying guilds is fair game?

> Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly.

What exactly does "dealt with accordingly" mean? Because "treating all users equally" would mean banning them. For the alts, if not for the siege.

But this kind of vague wording is usually used when admins want to do anything other than "deal with it accordingly", and just brush it under the rug with a slap on the wrist.

Would appreciate candid answers. Thanks.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

As a new user, who is looking for a platform that values free speech, it is rather discouraging to see this kind of organized commandeering and defacing of guilds, for expressing controversial ideas, with clear and expressed intent to shut those ideas down and drive them out. > All of this was possible due to @captainmeta4 's good communication and coordination with us, hopefully we can continue to clean up ruqqus together!

Is this true? Did you coordinate with them and thereby enable the siege?

> we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban

Does that include guilds like +GenderCriticaL and +AntiWhite, which were taken over more than 3 weeks ago? Why was there no intervention then?

> Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status

Does that mean that sieges, in general, are permitted? So having alts is a bannable offense, but maliciously stealing, defacing and destroying guilds is fair game?

> Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly.

What exactly does "dealt with accordingly" mean? Because "treating all users equally" would mean banning them. For the alts, if not for the siege.

But this kind of vague wording is usually used when admins want to do anything other than "deal with it accordingly", and just brush it under the rug with a slap on the wrist.

Would appreciate candid answers. Thanks.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

body:
Can you reconsider the punishment for breaking this rule? I think that a permaban is too harsh for it, especially because, as kek said in another comment, [someone could just forget about one of their alts](https://ruqqus.com/+uslashremoved/post/635k/josephgoebbels-banned-for-using-alts-to/l4s4) ( if someone forgot the password to one of their accounts with 10 guilds and didn't set an email, there's not much they could do about it) and end up modding more than 10 guilds. There's also the fact that some alt accounts are quite active (fifthfiend, for example). I think that there should be a 7 day ban for all alts unless the alt was only used for breaking the rule (as CrystalVulpine suggested), and I think that the user should decide which 10 guilds to keep (like Sloppyjosh suggested).

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

body:
Every new site goes through growing pains. As someone who once created and owned a fairly active message board back in the day when that sort thing was popular, I understand the headaches and push back. But I also highly respect the people who created and maintain this site @captainmeta4 @kek etc et all and that other guy. Doing this shit isn't easy. It takes a ton of energy, work, and most importantly Time, to create and moderate a site like this. 

And thats a lot of the problem. Some of you have no understanding or appreciation for the pain. You're like the people flipping fries who want to whinge and bitch about everything the corp does and claim you can do better. But you didn't. You didn't start the site and you aren't managing it. You're just bitching because you can. 

Some are jealous that YOU didn't think of this place---now you want to take over and make all it YOUR way because you're pissed you didn't or couldn't do it yourself---and frankly, your green monster petticoat is showing. It's not YOUR site. If you have that much of an issue with it, I hear there's a domain name that just became available yesterday on Dec 25....at around 12 noon, if you're interested in doing it all Your way. 

Some have legit complaints but damn...slow your roll. It's freaking Christmas, man. Drink some nog (I'm on my third) and go have a seat. If something is really wrong, it **will** get fixed. It doesn't need to get fixed right now, today, this instant. Frankly, if this my old site and you started up on Christmas, I'd have told you to fuck off and gone back to my prime rib leftovers. Cause that shit was amazing. And with all due respect, I think the mods are setting a dangerous precedent by responding immediately on a holiday. Some things aren't life and death. This site is not life and death. Frankly, your opinion and your current issue with whatever person/guild/moderator is not life and death--no matter how much you might want to believe it is. 

But spending time with your family eating prime rib leftovers *is* Life, and no one needs their needs met on an opinion site right this instant when people's family are waiting for them to sit down, enjoy the holiday, drink some Nog, and watch "A Christmas Story" with their kids...or even their dog. 

Ruqqus is an amazing place. It's not perfect, but we didn't come here for Perfect. We came here for the DumpsterFire. We Love the dumpster fire. The point of it is that none of us are perfect. We're muddling through the site, and our issues, and yeah, our hurt feewings about other places, and what we hope and dream and expect somewhere new. We're not Perfect, but we're all working on it. Give the mods time to work on it. Let them make mistakes, and learn from them. Let them enjoy their freaking nog. 

Go have a nog (starting my 4th). Enjoy Boxing Day. Enjoy your kids. Or your dog (or you cat). Enjoy my hangover tomorrow. 

Here's some demons to make the season bright. Some of ya'll act like these dudes look. To more nog... Null-ig hun-ah gwit! Sláinte

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mojrfw7SJ14&t=248s

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

How often is it going to be a legitimate concern vs people who are using multiple accounts in order to break the rules on purpose?

body:
>How often is it going to be a legitimate concern vs people who are using multiple accounts in order to break the rules on purpose?

Yeah, I'm guessing that most users who do this are probably breaking the rules on purpose. But even in that case, I don't quite think that the alts should be permabanned unless their sole purpose was for breaking this rule. Several users could have multiple different accounts that all are active enough to seem like main accounts, and I find it unfortunate that they'd only get to keep one of those accounts (even if they knowingly broke the rules). I think a 7-day ban for all alts seems like a good enough punishment until the user repeats the offence, in which case permabans would make sense.

>then why should you then turn around and care if your forgotten account that you can't use anymore anyway is permanently banned

I was actually thinking about other accounts they may have. Users often have more than one alt. One could've been used for evading the rules (so it makes sense to ban it), while another could've been a novelty account (so it won't make sense to permaban it).

Also, you don't necessarily have to forget about the account itself. You may just forget that your alts mod several guilds that your main doesn't, and if you create another guild on your main, you may unintentionally go over the 10 guild limit.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

>If someone can't be responsible enough with their multiple accounts to keep track of how many guilds they mod between them, then I think that losing their alts should serve as a much needed lesson in the responsible use of multiple accounts.

Eh, I have a different view from you then. I don't like harsh punishments and sometimes sympathize for those who break the rules. Yes, users should not knowingly break the rules (usually). post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.

There is really no ambiguity here. But, if judgment calls are against the spirit of the site, then the above suggestion would take care of most cases in an objective and impartial way.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.
